questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following best describes angiosarcoma?
questions.explanation:
Angiosarcoma is a malignant neoplasm. It is a vascular tumor arising from the endothelial cells. Benign vascular tumors are characterized by well-formed vascular channels lined by normal 
endothelial cells. Whereas, malignant vascular tumors are characterized by poorly formed vessels 
with cellular atypia.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following vascular tumors are not derived from endothelial cells?
questions.explanation:
Hemangiopericytoma is not derived from endothelial cells. It is a malignant vascular tumor 
derived from supporting cells of the blood vessels. Vascular tumors derived from endothelial cells are: • Hemangioma • Lymphangioma • Angiosarcoma The endothelial origin of vascular neoplasms can be confirmed using endothelial cell-specific 
markers such as CD31 or von Willebrand factor. 680 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is a true neoplasm?
questions.explanation:
Cystic hygroma / cavernous lymphangioma is a true neoplasm. It is a benign vascular tumor 
arising from endothelial cells. Options A and B: Nevus flammeus and port wine stain are vascular ectasias which are not true 
neoplasms. They are congenital or acquired malformations. Option D: Bacillary angiomatosis is non-neoplastic reactive vascular proliferation in response to 
opportunistic bacilli.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is the most common form of vascular ectasia?
questions.explanation:
The most common form of vascular ectasia is nevus flammeus. Vascular ectasias are the conditions involving the dilatation of blood vessels. They can be 
congenital or acquired malformations or hamartomas. Telangiectasia is the permanent dilation of 
small blood vessels. They lead to red lesions in the skin or mucous membranes. Various types of vascular ectasias are as follows: • Nevus flammeus (birthmark): Pink/purple flat lesions on the head or neck. They regress 
spontaneously. Image showing nevus flammeus in a newborn: • Port-wine stain: A special form of nevus flammeus. It thickens the skin surface. It grows during 
childhood and does not fade with time. Image showing port-wine stain in a child: 681 
Sold by @itachibot • Spider telangiectasias: They are pulsatile and blanch with pressure. These commonly occur on 
the face, neck, or upper chest. They are associated with hyperestrogenic states, such as pregnancy 
or liver cirrhosis. • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease) is caused by mutations in 
genes related to the TGF- signaling pathway. It is characterized by dilated blood vessels with thin 
walls that bleed easily. There can be bleeding from the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), 
tongue, mouth, eyes, and the gastrointestinal tract. The image below shows multiple flat non pulsating telengiectasias in a patient with 
Osler-Weber-Rendu disease: 682 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A young girl presents with recurrent seizures, mental retardation and a skin lesion as shown 
in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the facial port-wine stain as seen in the image is characteristic of 
Sturge-Weber syndrome. This is characterized by a triad of: • Facial port wine nevus - usually found in the distribution of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the 
trigeminal nerve • Glaucoma • Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) - can lead to seizures, mental retardation or 
hemiplegia and are seen as intracranial tram-track calcifications on CT as given below. 683 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements about hemangioma is true?

options.a: Capillary hemangioma is the most common type of hemangioma
options.b: Cavernous hemangioma usually regresses completely by 7 years of age
options.c: Juvenile hemangioma is infiltrative and does not regress spontaneously
options.d: Pyogenic granuloma is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus

questions.explanation:
The most common type of hemangioma is capillary hemangioma. Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy and childhood. They are of the following 
types: • Capillary hemangiomas are the most common type. They occur in the skin, subcutaneous 
tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips. • Cavernous hemangiomas are composed of large, dilated vascular channels. They are more 
infiltrative and frequently involve deep structures. They do not spontaneously regress. • Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. 
They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the 
age of 7 years. • Pyogenic granulomas are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red 
pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They bleed easily and are often 
ulcerated. It is not caused by bacterial infection.

questions.question:
Question 7: 674 
Sold by @itachibot A child is brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the right thigh. 
Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of capillary hemangioma in this patient. What is the 
most appropriate next best step?

options.a: Explain about the risk of malignant transformation of the tumor
options.b: Test the child for retrovirus infection
options.c: Enquire about history of exposure to polyvinyl chloride
options.d: Assure the parents about spontaneous regression of the tumor

questions.explanation:
Capillary hemangiomas are present from birth and initially increase in size, but many eventually 
regress spontaneously. They are generally benign. Images show the gross and microscopic pictures of capillary hemangioma: 684 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with bilateral pheochromocytoma is diagnosed with von Hippel-Lindau disease. 
This condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are 
commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver. Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective 
tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress 
spontaneously. The given image shows the microscopic appearance of cavernous hemangioma:

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following vascular lesions are commonly seen in patients with Turner 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
685 
Sold by @itachibot The vascular lesions commonly seen in Turner syndrome are cavernous lymphangiomas of the 
neck. Cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygromas) are massively dilated lymphatic spaces lined by 
endothelial cells and separated by connective tissue stroma. They are typically found in the neck 
or axilla of children and rarely in the retroperitoneum. They can be enormous causing gross 
deformities around the neck. Image shows cavernous lymphangioma of the neck associated with a girl having Turner 
syndrome:

questions.question:
Question 10: A middle aged male patient presents with a swelling on his left thumb as shown in the image 
below. Which of the following statements about this swelling is false? 675 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is caused by a bacterial infection
options.d: It is a type of capillary hemangioma

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a pyogenic granuloma. It is not caused by bacterial infection. The term 
pyogenic granuloma is a misnomer as it neither contains pus nor is it a granulomatous lesion. These are capillary hemangiomas that appear as red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or 
oral mucosa. They are most commonly benign. They tend to grow rapidly, bleed easily and are 
often ulcerated. Histologic image of pyogenic granuloma: 686 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Granuloma gravidarum is a type of  
.
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy tumor or granuloma gravidarum is a type of pyogenic granuloma that occurs 
infrequently in gingiva of pregnant women. These lesions may spontaneously regress, especially after pregnancy, or they may undergo 
fibrosis. Occasionally, they require surgical excision.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following vascular tumors arising from arteriovenous structures is involved in 
thermoregulation?
questions.explanation:
The vascular tumor arising from arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation is glomus 
tumor. These tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies which are specialized 
arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. They are benign but extremely painful due 
to abundant nerve fibers. Histopathology shows branching vascular channels separated by stroma containing glomus cells 
in nests: 687 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common site of glomus tumors?
questions.explanation:
Glomus tumors are most commonly found in the distal portion of the digits, especially under the 
fingernails.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 46-year-old HIV-positive female patient presents with fever, weight loss, and cutaneous 
lesions as shown in the image. Microscopic examination reveals capillary proliferation and 
neutrophilic infiltration. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette and the microscopic findings suggest the diagnosis of bacillary 
angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae. Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular proliferation in immunocompromised hosts caused by 
opportunistic gram-negative bacilli of the Bartonella family like Bartonella henselae 688 
Sold by @itachibot and Bartonella quintana. These lesions can involve the skin, bone, brain, and other organs. They contain stromal 
neutrophils, nuclear dust, and causal bacteria. Histology shows capillary proliferation with 
endothelial cells exhibiting nuclear atypia and mitosis. Modified silver (Warthin-Starry) stain is used for demonstrating clusters of tangled bacilli. The given image shows histologic appearance of bacillary angiomatosis:

questions.question:
Question 15: A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with skin lesions over the distal portion of the 
lower limbs as shown in the image below. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating 
spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following 677 
Sold by @itachibot is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi 
sarcoma. Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly 
associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs 
in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent. It has the following three clinical 
stages: • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally. • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to 
involve nodes and viscera. Diseases caused by HHV-8 infection primarily in patients with HIV infection include: • Kaposi sarcoma • Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD) • Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) The given image shows sheets of proliferating spindle cells: 689 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which type of Kaposi sarcoma is most commonly seen in patients with HIV infection?
questions.explanation:
AIDS-associated or epidemic Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an AIDS-defining illness, and worldwide, it 
represents the most common HIV-related malignancy. Four forms of KS are recognized, based on population demographics and risks: Type

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with vague upper abdominal pain is diagnosed with hemangioendothelioma of the 
liver. What is this classified as?
questions.explanation:
Hemangioendothelioma is classified as intermediate-grade neoplasm. It encompasses a spectrum 
of vascular neoplasms with clinical behavior intermediate between benign well-differentiated 
hemangiomas and anaplastic angiosarcomas.

questions.question:
Question 18: An elderly male working in a factory manufacturing PVC pipes is at risk of developing which 
of the following cancers?
questions.explanation:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with carcinogenic exposures to polyvinyl chloride. 690 
Sold by @itachibot Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that primarily affects older adults. The tumor 
often involves the skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. Angiosarcomas are locally invasive and can 
readily metastasize.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is the most common causative agent for lymphangitis?
questions.explanation:
Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci are the most common agents responsible for lymphangitis. Lymphangitis represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into 
lymphatics. It is manifested by red, painful subcutaneous streaks (the inflamed lymphatics) and 
painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). Filariasis causes obstructive lymphedema and chronic lymphadenitis.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following best describes Milroy disease?
questions.explanation:
Milroy disease refers to heredofamilial congenital lymphedema. Causes of lymphedema: Primary lymphedema: • Simple congenital lymphedema • Heredofamilial congenital lymphedema (Milroy disease) Secondary or obstructive lymphedema: • Malignant tumors obstructing lymphatic channels • Surgical removal of regional groups of lymph nodes, e.g., radical mastectomy • Postirradiation fibrosis • Filariasis • Post-inflammatory thrombosis and scarring 691 
Sold by @itachibot Heart Failure and Ischemic Disease
